Private sampling: a noiseless approach for generating differentially private synthetic data

March Boedihardjo Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine marchb@uci.edu ,Â  Thomas Strohmer Center of Data Science and Artificial Intelligence Research University of California, Davis
and Department of Mathematics, University of California Davis strohmer@math.ucdavis.edu Â andÂ  Roman Vershynin Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine rvershyn@uci.edu
Abstract.

In a world where artificial intelligence and data science become omnipresent, data sharing is increasingly locking horns with data-privacy concerns. Differential privacy has emerged as a rigorous framework for protecting individual privacy in a statistical database, while releasing useful statistical information about the database. The standard way to implement differential privacy is to inject a sufficient amount of noise into the data. However, in addition to other limitations of differential privacy, this process of adding noise will affect data accuracy and utility. Another approach to enable privacy in data sharing is based on the concept of synthetic data. The goal of synthetic data is to create an as-realistic-as-possible dataset, one that not only maintains the nuances of the original data, but does so without risk of exposing sensitive information. The combination of differential privacy with synthetic data has been suggested as a best-of-both-worlds solutions. In this work, we propose the first noisefree method to construct differentially private synthetic data; we do this through a mechanism called â€œprivate samplingâ€. Using the Boolean cube as benchmark data model, we derive explicit bounds on accuracy and privacy of the constructed synthetic data. The key mathematical tools are hypercontractivity, duality, and empirical processes. A core ingredient of our private sampling mechanism is a rigorous â€œmarginal correctionâ€ method, which has the remarkable property that importance reweighting can be utilized to exactly match the marginals of the sample to the marginals of the population.

1. Introduction

In a world where artificial intelligence and data science are penetrating more and more aspects of our life, data sharing is increasingly locking horns with data-privacy concerns. This conflict is playing out around the globe, as private and public organizations are trying to find ways to share data without compromising sensitive personal information.

There exist various attempts to protect sensitive information in data. Historically the way to share private information without betraying privacy was through anonymizationÂ [45], i.e., by stripping away enough identifying information from a dataset, so that the so-modified data could be shared freely. Anonymization, however, proved to be a fragile means to protect data privacy. In actuality, identifying individuals using seemingly non-unique identifiers is far easier than proponents of data anonymization expected. For instance, Netflix and AOL customers were all accurately identified from purportedly anonymized data. De-identification requires precise definitions of â€œunique identifiersâ€. Furthermore, de-identification suffers from an aging problem: it is already quite difficult enough to determine exactly what data identifies information that needs to be protected (say, the identity of individuals), but it is even more difficult to accurately predict what potential auxiliary information could be available in the future. This leads to an arms race between de-identification and re-identification.

The well-documented failures of anonymization have prompted aggressive research on data sanitization, ranging from kğ‘˜k-anonymityÂ [38, 5] to todayâ€™s highly acclaimed differential privacyÂ [21]. The concept of k-anonymity was introduced to address the risk of re-identification of anonymized data through linkage to other datasets. The idea behind kğ‘˜k-anonymity is to maintain privacy by guaranteeing that for every record in a database there are kğ‘˜k of indistinguishable copies.

Differential privacy is a framework to quantify the extent to which individual privacy in a statistical database is preserved while releasing useful statistical information about the databaseÂ [21]. Differential privacy is a popular and robust method that comes with a rigorous mathematical framework and provable guarantees. Differential privacy can protect aggregate information, but not sensitive information in general. Also, if enough identical queries are asked, the protection provided by differential privacy is diluted. Additionally, if the query being asked requires high specificity, then it is more difficult to uphold differential privacy. In any case, in all the aforementioned methods the basic tradeoff between utility and privacy represents a serious limitation.

Synthetic data provide a promising concept to solve this conundrumÂ [7]. The goal of synthetic data is to create an as-realistic-as-possible dataset, one that not only maintains the nuances of the original data, but does so without risk of exposing sensitive information. Synthetic datasets are generated from existing datasets and maintain the statistical properties of the original dataset. Since (ideally) synthetic data contain no protected information, the datasets can be shared freely among investigators in academia or industry, without security and privacy concerns.

It has been frequently recommended that synthetic data may be combined with differential privacy to achieve a best-of-both-worlds scenarioÂ [23, 7, 27, 29, 10]. As observed inÂ [7], â€œThe most ideal data to use in any analysis will always be original data. But when that option is not available, synthetic data plus differential privacy offers a great compromise.â€ Synthetic data are not only a succinct way of representing the answers to large numbers of queries, but they also permit one to carry out other data analysis tasks, such as visualization or regression.

The standard way to achieve differential privacy is to add noise, either to the data queries, the data themselves, or in case of synthetic data during the data generation process, for a small sample of work see e.g.Â [21, 23, 24, 3, 29, 16]. Unfortunately, noise will negatively affect utility and can inject systematic errorsâ€”hence biasâ€”into the dataÂ [36, 47, 22]. To illustrate these issues, assume the dataset under consideration consists of images, each depicting the face of a person. We can attempt to generate a differentially private synthetic dataset by adding a sufficient amount of noise to each image (e.g., by adding random noiseÂ [32] or by distorting or blurring the imagesÂ [37, 44]), such that the persons in the images can no longer be identified. Ignoring for the moment the possibility of re-identifying a person by applying denoising or deblurring techniques to the distorted images, it is clear that utility of this dataset can decrease significantly during this process of adding noise, perhaps to the point that many of the nuances one might be interested in are no longer present.

To illuminate the effect of introducing systematic error when adding noise to ensure differential privacy, we just need to look at the issues reported with differentially private US Census 2020 demonstration data, which have resulted in diminished quality of statistics for small populations such as tribal nationsÂ [42, 36, 22].

These considerations raise a fundamental question:

Can we generate differentially private synthetic data without adding noise?

In this paper, we give a positive and constructive answer. Using the Boolean cube as our data model, we will develop a noiseless method to generate synthetic data, which approximately preserve low-dimensional marginals of the original dataset. Our method is based on a private sampling framework and comes with explicit bounds on privacy and accuracy. The key mathematical tools are hypercontractivity, duality, and empirical processes. A core ingredient of our private sampling framework is a rigorous â€œmarginal correctionâ€ method, which has the remarkable property that importance reweighting can be utilized to exactly match the marginals of the sample to the marginals of the population.

There exist other methods to generate differentially private synthetic data without adding noise, such as those based on generative adversarial networksÂ [30, 1, 12, 46, 17]. However, these methods are just empirical and do not come with any rigorous bounds regarding accuracy or privacy. Those deep learning based methods that do come with privacy guaranteesâ€”but still without any accuracy guaranteesâ€”require injecting noise into the synthetic data generation processÂ [43, 26, 6].

2. Synthetic data and differential privacy

Differential privacy has emerged as the de facto standard for guaranteeing privacy in data sharing. Recall the definition of differential privacy:

Definition 2.1 (Differential PrivacyÂ [21]).

A randomized mechanism â„³:ğ’®Nâ†’â„›:â„³superscriptğ’®ğ‘â†’â„›{\mathcal{M}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}{\mathcal{S}}^{N}\to{\mathcal{R}} satisfies Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differential privacy if for any two adjacent datasets X1,X2âˆˆğ’®Nsubscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹2superscriptğ’®ğ‘X_{1},X_{2}\in{\mathcal{S}}^{N} differing by one element, and any output subset ğ’ªâˆˆâ„›ğ’ªâ„›{\mathcal{O}}\in{\mathcal{R}} it holds that

â„™â€‹[â„³â€‹(X1)âˆˆğ’ª]â‰¤eÎµâ‹…â„™â€‹[â„³â€‹(X2)âˆˆğ’ª].â„™delimited-[]â„³subscriptğ‘‹1ğ’ªâ‹…superscriptğ‘’ğœ€â„™delimited-[]â„³subscriptğ‘‹2ğ’ª{\mathbb{P}}[{\mathcal{M}}(X_{1})\in{\mathcal{O}}]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\cdot{\mathbb{P}}[{\mathcal{M}}(X_{2})\in{\mathcal{O}}].

Numerous techniques have been proposed for generating privacy-preserving synthetic data (e.g.Â [2, 13, 1, 15, 31]), but without providing formal privacy guarantees. Almost all existing mechanisms to implement differential privacy inject some sort of noise into the data or the data queries, see e.g.Â the Laplacian mechanismÂ [19]. This is also the case for differentially private synthetic data, see for instanceÂ [28, 4].

Obviously, we want our synthetic data to be similar to the original data. To that end we need some metrics to measure similarity. A common and natural choice is to try to (approximately) preserve low-dimensional marginalsÂ [4, 39]. A marginal of the data Xğ‘‹X is the fraction of the elements xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} with specified values of specified parameters. On the one hand, marginals are important in their own right as a tool of statistical analysis. On the other hand, if the synthetic data preserve e.g.Â two-dimensional marginals (i.e., covariance matrices) with sufficient accuracy, the synthetic dataset is expected to inherit other significant properties from the original dataset, such as similar behavior with respect to clustering, classification or regression111So far this expectation has only been verified empirically in various papers, while a rigorous mathematical verification is an important open problem..

However, we are immediately met with a remarkable no-go theorem due to Ullman and VadhanÂ [40]. They proved the surprising result that (under standard cryptographic assumptions) there is no polynomial-time differentially private algorithm that takes a dataset Xâˆˆ({0,1}p)nğ‘‹superscriptsuperscript01ğ‘ğ‘›X\in(\{0,1\}^{p})^{n} and outputs a synthetic dataset Yâˆˆ({0,1}p)kğ‘Œsuperscriptsuperscript01ğ‘ğ‘˜Y\in(\{0,1\}^{p})^{k} such that all two-dimensional marginals of Yğ‘ŒY are approximately equal to those of Xğ‘‹X.

There is an extensive literature on privately releasing answers to linear queries, but without producing synthetic data, see e.g.Â [25, 33, 20] for a small sample. Another line of important work deals with with privacy-preserving data analysis in a statistical frameworkÂ [18, 14]; but they also are not concerned with synthetic data. The papersÂ [4, 24, 23, 9] propose a range of interesting methods for producing approximately accurate private synthetic data. However, the associated algorithms have running time that is at least exponential in pğ‘p.

Luckily, already a slightly relaxed formulation of the worst-case no-go result inÂ [40] already leads to positive results. For example, if we relax â€œall marginalsâ€ to â€œmost marginalsâ€, it is shown inÂ [10] that there exists a polynomial-time differentially private algorithm generating synthetic data Yâˆˆ({0,1}p)kğ‘Œsuperscriptsuperscript01ğ‘ğ‘˜Y\in(\{0,1\}^{p})^{k} such that the error between the marginals of Yğ‘ŒY and Xğ‘‹X is small. Remarkably, the result does not only hold for two-dimensional marginals, but for marginals of all dimensions. If we relax â€œworst dataâ€ to â€œtypical dataâ€, generating accurate differentially private synthetic Boolean (or other domain constrained) data becomes tractableÂ [11].

Yet, in all the aforementioned papers differential privacy is achieved by adding noise during the data generation process. In this paper we propose an alternative, noise-free, mechanism called private sampling.

3. Main result

We model the true data X=(x1,â€¦,xn)ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›X=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) as a sequence of nğ‘›n points from the Boolean cube {0,1}psuperscript01ğ‘\{0,1\}^{p}, which is a standard benchmark data modelÂ [4, 40, 23, 35, 29, 8]. For example, Xğ‘‹X might represent the health records of nğ‘›n patients, where each health record consists of pğ‘p parameters. These parameters are 0/1010/1 numbers that represent the answers to the standard health history questionnaire, such as â€œdoes the patient smoke?â€, â€œdoes the patient have diabetes?â€. We can also represent categorical data (gender, occupation, etc.) or numerical data (by splitting them into intervals) on the Boolean cube via binary or one-hot encoding.

We would like to manufacture a synthetic dataset Y=(y1,â€¦,yk)ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜Y=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{k}), another sequence of kğ‘˜k elements of the cube. Our two desiderata are privacy and accuracy. Specifically, we would like the synthetic data to be differentially private, and all low-dimensional marginals of Yğ‘ŒY to exactly or approximately match those of Xğ‘‹X.

3.2. Difficulties and their resolution

Unfortunately, the density hâˆ—superscriptâ„h^{*} guaranteed by TheoremÂ 3.1 is too sensitive. Indeed, the sensitivity bound in LemmaÂ 3.3 needs to be proved for arbitrary input data, while TheoremÂ 3.1 only works with high probability. For some input data Xğ‘‹X, a suitable density exists, and for another input data Zğ‘Z, no suitable density exists. Moving from Xğ‘‹X toward Zğ‘Z by changing one data point at a time, we can find a pair of datasets X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1} and X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2} that differ in a single data point so that the algorithm succeeds to find a density for X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1} and fails for X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2}. This means that the algorithm is non-private.

The other issue is that there can be (and usually are) many suitable densities hâˆ—superscriptâ„h^{*}. Which one to chose? How to devise a selection rule that upholds privacy?

In other words, we need to work around the possible non-existence and non-uniqueness of the solution. We resolve both issues here. To ensure existence, we employ shrinking: we move the solution space (the set of all functions on Sğ‘†S, possibly negative-valued, that have the same marginals as Xğ‘‹X) toward the uniform density on Sğ‘†S until the resulting set contains a nonnegative function (thus a density). For the selection rule, we choose the closest solution to the uniform density on Sğ‘†S in the L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2} metric.

Furthermore, while Sğ‘†S is chosen randomly, we do need Sğ‘†S to be well-conditioned in a sense that will be discussed in detail in SectionÂ 9. At this point suffice it to say that (i)Â the well-conditionedness of Sğ‘†S can be expressed in terms of a bound on the smallest singular value Ïƒminâ€‹(M)subscriptğœğ‘€\sigma_{\min}(M) of the mÃ—(pâ‰¤d)ğ‘šbinomialğ‘absentğ‘‘m\times\binom{p}{\leq d} matrix Mğ‘€M with entries wâ€‹(s)ğ‘¤ğ‘ w(s), where sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in S and wğ‘¤w is a Walsh function444See SectionÂ 4 for basic definitions related to Fourier analysis of the Boolean cube. of degree at most dğ‘‘d; (ii)Â the well-conditionedness of Mğ‘€M can be easily achieved and easily verified.

This leads us to the algorithm outlined in the next subsection.

3.3. Algorithm

We provide a high-level description of our proposed method in AlgorithmÂ 1.

The well-conditionedness of Sğ‘†S in AlgorithmÂ 1 defined via the condition Ïƒminâ€‹(M)>m/2â€‹edsubscriptğœğ‘€ğ‘š2superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‘\sigma_{\min}(M)>\sqrt{m}/2e^{d} essentially says that the subsampled Walsh basis is almost orthogonal. The scaling mğ‘š\sqrt{m} is natural: the entries of Mğ‘€M all have absolute value 111, hence the columns of Mğ‘€M have Euclidean norm mğ‘š\sqrt{m}. If we had Ïƒminâ€‹(M)=msubscriptğœğ‘€ğ‘š\sigma_{\min}(M)=\sqrt{m}, this would imply that the columns of Mğ‘€M (the subsampled Walsh functions) are mutually orthogonal. We require a relaxed (by a factor 2â€‹ed2superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‘2e^{d}) version of this orthogonality.

What if Sğ‘†S fails the desired condition? We can simply resample Sğ‘†S until it is well conditioned. But this is only a useful strategy if the chances of success are sufficiently high. Under some mild conditions (see SectionÂ 9) success happens with probability >1/2absent12>1/2, hence the expected number or trials until success is â‰¤2absent2\leq 2. This way AlgorithmÂ 1 succeeds deterministically, but its running time becomes random (albeit with the rather modest expected overhead time â‰¤2absent2\leq 2).


Definition 3.4.

We say that the synthetic dataset Yğ‘ŒY is Î´ğ›¿\delta-accurate if each of its marginals up to degree (or dimension) dğ‘‘d is within Î´ğ›¿\delta from the corresponding marginal of the true dataset Xğ‘‹X.

A formal version of part (a) of TheoremÂ 3.5 is shown in PropositionÂ 9.3; part (b) is shown in TheoremÂ 12.2 and RemarkÂ 12.3; part (c) is shown in TheoremÂ 12.4. The mathematical techniques to prove these results revolve around Fourier analysis of Boolean functions and empirical processes, see SectionsÂ 4â€“7.

In case the true data Xğ‘‹X is sampled form a regular density, the algorithm will not apply any shrinkage, since in this case TheoremÂ 3.1 guarantees the existence of a solution. (We make this rigorous in RemarkÂ 12.5.) In this case, the private synthetic data Yğ‘ŒY will be sampled in an unbiased way from the density hâˆ—superscriptâ„h^{*} that has exactly the same marginals as the true data Xğ‘‹X.

3.4. Further remarks

There is a one-sample version of TheoremÂ 3.1. Let us state it here informally; a more accurate statement is given in TheoremÂ 8.2.

Theorem 3.6 (Marginal correction).

Consider a regularly varying density fğ‘“f on the cube {0,1}psuperscript01ğ‘\{0,1\}^{p} and draw an independent sample Sğ‘†S from the cube according to this distribution. If |S|â‰«e2â€‹dâ€‹(pâ‰¤d)much-greater-thanğ‘†superscriptğ‘’2ğ‘‘binomialğ‘absentğ‘‘\mathinner{\!\left\lvert S\right\rvert}\gg e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}, then with probability 1âˆ’oâ€‹(1)1ğ‘œ11-o(1) there exists a density hâ„h on Sğ‘†S that has exactly the same marginals as fğ‘“f up to dimension dğ‘‘d. Moreover, hâ„h is within a 1+oâ€‹(1)1ğ‘œ11+o(1) factor of the uniform density on Sğ‘†S.

The law of large numbers tells us that the sample Sğ‘†S must have approximately the same marginals as the density fğ‘“f from which Sğ‘†S was drawn. TheoremÂ 3.6 tells us that we can make the marginals exactly the same by a slight reweighting of Sğ‘†S, i.e. by weights that are all 1+oâ€‹(1)1ğ‘œ11+o(1).

4. Fourier analysis

The proof of TheoremÂ 3.1 is based on hypercontractivity, duality, and empirical processes.

6. Enforcing a uniform bound and sparsity

8.1. Proof of TheoremÂ 3.1

9. Solution space

Our next focus is on proving TheoremÂ 3.5, which gives guarantees for privacy and accuracy of the synthetic data created by AlgorithmÂ 1.

Let us formally introduce the solution space â€“ the space of all functions on the reduced sample space Sğ‘†S that have the same marginals as a given function uğ‘¢u.

Definition 9.1 (Solution space).

Let Î¼ğœ‡\mu be a probability measure on the cube {âˆ’1,1}psuperscript11ğ‘\{-1,1\}^{p}, and Î¼msubscriptğœ‡ğ‘š\mu_{m} be its empirical counterpart. The AlgorithmÂ 1 succeeds, i.e. does not return â€œFailureâ€, when the reduced space S={Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸m}ğ‘†subscriptğœƒ1â€¦subscriptğœƒğ‘šS=\{\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{m}\} is well conditioned. By definition, this happens if

Let us reformulate the condition (9.1) in the dual form, and then deduce from TheoremÂ 6.1 that that it holds with high probability.

10. Selection rule

Next, we want to extend sensitivity to the selection rule. Can we pick one point from a solution space in such a way that a small change in the solution space always leads to a small change in the selected point?

10.1. L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2} sensitivity

We do not know the best selection rule in the Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿L^{\infty} metric. The problem is simpler for the L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2} metric: the proximal point (to a given reference point) is a good selection rule.

11. Shrinkage

Another step of AlgorithmÂ 1 we need to control is shrinkage. We will check here that shrinkage onto a cube is Lipschitz in the Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿L^{\infty}-Hausdorff metric. Let us start with a general observation:

Let Xğ‘‹X be a normed space and zâˆˆXğ‘§ğ‘‹z\in X be a point such that âˆ¥zâˆ¥â‰¤1âˆ’Î²delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘§1ğ›½\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}\leq 1-\beta for some Î²âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›½01\beta\in(0,1). To prove the second part of the lemma, we need to show that

Finally, we specialize our analysis to the shrinkage onto the cube:

12. Privacy and accuracy of the algorithm

We are ready to analyze the privacy and accuracy of AlgorithmÂ 1.

12.1. Algorithm

For convenience we rewrite AlgorithmÂ 1, see AlgorithmÂ 2 below. Also note that in Step 5 of AlgorithmÂ 2, the L2â€‹(S)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘†L^{2}(S)-norm is defined as âˆ¥hâˆ¥L2â€‹(S)2=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mhâ€‹(si)2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥â„superscriptğ¿2ğ‘†21ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h\right\rVert}_{L^{2}(S)}^{2}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}h(s_{i})^{2}.

The standing assumption in this section is that the reduced space S=(s1,â€¦,sm)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘šS=(s_{1},\ldots,s_{m}) is random, and consists of points sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} drawn independently and uniformly from the cube. We would like to show that with high probability over Sğ‘†S, the algorithm is differentially private.

12.2. Sensitivity of density

The privacy guarantee will be achieved via Private Sampling LemmaÂ 3.3. To apply it, we need to bound the sensitivity of the density hâˆ—superscriptâ„h^{*} computed by the algorithm.

12.3. Privacy guarantee

Finally, we are ready to give the privacy guarantee of our algorithm:

Theorem 12.2 (Privacy).

If kâ‰¤14â€‹2â€‹Îµâ€‹(Î´/Î”)3/2â€‹eâˆ’d/2â€‹(pâ‰¤d)âˆ’1/4â€‹n/m3/4ğ‘˜142ğœ€superscriptğ›¿Î”32superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‘2superscriptbinomialğ‘absentğ‘‘14ğ‘›superscriptğ‘š34k\leq\frac{1}{4\sqrt{2}}\varepsilon(\delta/\Delta)^{3/2}e^{-d/2}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{-1/4}\sqrt{n}/m^{3/4}, then AlgorithmÂ 2 is Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private.

Proof.

Since the reduced space Sğ‘†S is drawn independently of the input data Xğ‘‹X, we can condition on Sğ‘†S. If Sğ‘†S is ill conditioned, the algorithm returns â€œFailureâ€ regardless of the input data, so the privacy holds trivially. Suppose Sğ‘†S is well conditioned.

Let X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1} and X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2} be a pair of datasets that consist of at least nğ‘›n elements each and differ from each other by a single element. By the choice made in the algorithm and by sensitivity of density (LemmaÂ 12.1), we have

h2âˆ—â‰¥Î´mand|h1âˆ—âˆ’h2âˆ—|â‰¤4â€‹2â€‹Î”3/2â€‹ed/2Î´â€‹nâ€‹m1/4â€‹(pâ‰¤d)1/4â‰•Î·formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptâ„2ğ›¿ğ‘šandsubscriptsuperscriptâ„1subscriptsuperscriptâ„242superscriptÎ”32superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‘2ğ›¿ğ‘›superscriptğ‘š14superscriptbinomialğ‘absentğ‘‘14â‰•ğœ‚h^{*}_{2}\geq\frac{\delta}{m}\quad\text{and}\quad\mathinner{\!\left\lvert h^{*}_{1}-h^{*}_{2}\right\rvert}\leq\frac{4\sqrt{2}\Delta^{3/2}e^{d/2}}{\sqrt{\delta n}\,m^{1/4}}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/4}\eqqcolon\eta

pointwise. Therefore

|h1âˆ—/h2âˆ—|â‰¤1+Î·â€‹mÎ´â‰¤expâ¡(Î·â€‹mÎ´)â‰¤expâ¡(Îµk)subscriptsuperscriptâ„1subscriptsuperscriptâ„21ğœ‚ğ‘šğ›¿ğœ‚ğ‘šğ›¿ğœ€ğ‘˜\mathinner{\!\left\lvert h^{*}_{1}/h^{*}_{2}\right\rvert}\leq 1+\frac{\eta m}{\delta}\leq\exp\Big{(}\frac{\eta m}{\delta}\Big{)}\leq\exp\Big{(}\frac{\varepsilon}{k}\Big{)}

pointwise, where the last inequality indeed holds due to our assumption on kğ‘˜k. Private Sampling LemmaÂ 3.3 completes the proof. âˆ

Remark 12.3.

Suppose we chose the size mğ‘šm of the reduced space Sğ‘†S so that mâ‰e2â€‹dâ€‹(pâ‰¤d)asymptotically-equalsğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘’2ğ‘‘binomialğ‘absentğ‘‘m\asymp e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}.
